metadata.title: Collaboration and sharing | Apple Developer Documentation
metadata.author: Apple Inc.
metadata.summary: Apple Developer Documentation page providing comprehensive guidance on implementing collaboration and sharing features in apps across Apple platforms. The document covers best practices for using system interfaces, Messages integration, share sheets, collaboration buttons, and platform-specific considerations.

content.text: Great collaboration and sharing experiences are simple and responsive, letting people engage with the content while communicating effectively with others.

System interfaces and the Messages app can help you provide consistent and convenient ways for people to collaborate and share. For example, people can share content or begin a collaboration by dropping a document into a Messages conversation or selecting a destination in the familiar share sheet.

After a collaboration begins, people can use the Collaboration button in your app to communicate with others, perform custom actions, and manage details. In addition, people can receive Messages notifications when collaborators mention them, make changes, join, or leave.

You can take advantage of Messages integration and the system-provided sharing interfaces whether you implement collaboration and sharing through CloudKit, iCloud Drive, or a custom solution. To offer these features when you use a custom collaboration infrastructure, make sure your app also supports universal links (for developer guidance, see Supporting universal links in your app).

inlineLinks.text: Supporting universal links in your app

content.text: In addition to helping people share and collaborate on documents, visionOS supports immersive sharing experiences through SharePlay. For guidance, see SharePlay.

content.leadText: Place the Share button in a convenient location, like a toolbar, to make it easy for people to start sharing or collaborating.
content.bodyText: In iOS 16, the system-provided share sheet includes ways to choose a file-sharing method and set permissions for a new collaboration; iPadOS 16 and macOS 13 introduce similar appearance and functionality in the sharing popover. In your SwiftUI app, you can also enable sharing by presenting a share link that opens the system-provided share sheet when people choose it; for developer guidance, see ShareLink.

content.description: An illustration showing an iOS interface mockup with a Share button in a toolbar. The image depicts a document or content area with a navigation bar at the top. The Share button (square with upward arrow icon) is prominently displayed in the toolbar area. The illustration uses a warm color palette with orange/coral accent colors.
content.composition: Centered illustration showing a simplified iOS app interface with focus on the Share button placement in the toolbar
content.technicalDetails: Simplified iOS interface mockup showing toolbar with Share button
content.contextualRelevance: Demonstrates the recommended placement of the Share button in a convenient location like a toolbar
content.caption: Helene Walks

content.leadText: If necessary, customize the share sheet or sharing popover to offer the types of file sharing your app supports.
content.bodyText: If you use CloudKit, you can add support for sending a copy of a file by passing both the file and your collaboration object to the share sheet. Because the share sheet has built-in support for multiple items, it automatically detects the file and makes the "send copy" functionality available. With iCloud Drive, your collaboration object supports "send copy" functionality by default. For custom collaboration, you can support "send copy" functionality in the share sheet by including a file — or a plain text representation of it — in your collaboration object.

content.leadText: Write succinct phrases that summarize the sharing permissions you support.
content.bodyText: For example, you might write phrases like "Only invited people can edit" or "Everyone can make changes." The system uses your permission summary in a button that reveals a set of sharing options that people use to define the collaboration.

content.description: An illustration showing iOS sharing permissions UI elements. The image displays multiple UI components related to collaboration permissions including permission summary buttons and sharing options. The design uses warm orange/coral accent colors consistent with the Apple design language. Shows examples of permission text like collaboration access settings.
content.composition: Multiple UI elements arranged to show the flow of setting sharing permissions
content.contextualRelevance: Illustrates how to present sharing permission summaries in the UI

content.leadText: Provide a set of simple sharing options that streamline collaboration setup.
content.bodyText: You can customize the view that appears when people choose the permission summary button to provide choices that reflect your collaboration functionality. For example, you might offer options that let people specify who can access the content and whether they can edit it or just read it, and whether collaborators can add new participants. Keep the number of custom choices to a minimum and group them in ways that help people understand them at a glance.

content.leadText: Prominently display the Collaboration button as soon as collaboration starts.
content.bodyText: The system-provided Collaboration button reminds people that the content is shared and identifies who's sharing it. Because the Collaboration button typically appears after people interact with the share sheet or sharing popover, it works well to place it next to the Share button.

content.description: An illustration showing the Collaboration button placement in an iOS toolbar. The image depicts a document interface with the Collaboration button (showing multiple person icons indicating shared content) displayed prominently next to the Share button. The toolbar shows the typical iOS navigation pattern with the collaboration indicator visible.
content.composition: Focused view of toolbar area showing Collaboration button next to Share button
content.technicalDetails: iOS toolbar mockup with Collaboration button
content.contextualRelevance: Shows recommended placement of Collaboration button next to Share button
content.caption: Helene Walks

content.leadText: Provide custom actions in the collaboration popover only if needed.
content.bodyText: Choosing the Collaboration button in your app reveals a popover that consists of three sections. The top section lists collaborators and provides communication buttons that can open Messages or FaceTime, the middle section contains your custom items, and the bottom section displays a button people use to manage the shared file. You don't want to overwhelm people with too much information, so it's crucial to offer only the most essential items that people need while they use your app to collaborate. For example, Notes summarizes the most recent updates and provides buttons that let people get more information about the updates or view more activities.

content.description: A detailed mockup or screenshot of the Notes app collaboration popover on iOS. The popover shows three distinct sections: 1) Top section with collaborator avatars/icons and communication buttons (Messages, FaceTime), 2) Middle section with custom actions showing recent updates summary with buttons for more information, 3) Bottom section with 'Manage Shared Note' button. The design uses Apple's standard popover styling with rounded corners and subtle shadows.
content.composition: Vertical popover layout with three distinct sections stacked
content.technicalDetails: iOS Notes app collaboration popover showing the three-section structure
content.contextualRelevance: Demonstrates the collaboration popover structure and how Notes implements custom actions

content.leadText: If it makes sense in your app, customize the title of the modal view's collaboration-management button.
content.bodyText: People choose this button — titled "Manage Shared File" by default — to reveal the collaboration-management view where they can change settings and add or remove collaborators. If you use CloudKit sharing, the system provides a management view for you; otherwise, you create your own.

content.description: An illustration showing the customization of the collaboration management button. Displays examples of button titles that can be customized, showing both the default 'Manage Shared File' text and custom alternatives. The illustration uses the consistent orange/coral accent color scheme.
content.composition: Comparison or example view of button customization options
content.contextualRelevance: Shows how to customize the collaboration management button title

content.leadText: Consider posting collaboration event notifications in Messages.
content.bodyText: Choose the type of event that occurred — such as a change in the content or the collaboration membership, or the mention of a participant — and include a universal link people can use to open the relevant view in your app. For developer guidance, see SWHighlightEvent.

content.text: No additional considerations for iOS, iPadOS, or macOS. Not available in tvOS.

By default, the system supports screen sharing for an app running in the Shared Space by streaming the current window to other collaborators. If one person transitions the app to a Full Space while sharing is in progress, the system pauses the stream for other people until the app returns to the Shared Space. For guidance, see Immersive experiences.
In your SwiftUI app running in watchOS, use ShareLink to present the system-provided share sheet.

pages.pageSummary: This is the complete Apple Developer Documentation page for 'Collaboration and sharing' which provides comprehensive guidance on implementing collaboration features in apps. The page covers system interfaces, Messages integration, share sheets, collaboration buttons, and includes platform-specific considerations for iOS, iPadOS, macOS, visionOS, watchOS, and tvOS. The page features multiple illustrative images showing UI patterns and includes a change log tracking document revisions.
